prior_accusations.context: accused her some two years earlier

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacote Marechal (threat to Claudatte)
notable_quotes.french: que le diable avoit bien tant laisse vivre icelle Claudatte pour prester de l'argent
notable_quotes.english: that the devil had let Claudatte live so long just to lend money
notable_quotes.context: anger over lending money for field repurchase

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacote Marechal (threat about battand)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle donnoit au diable ledit battand, et celuy qui avoit donné la permission de le bastir, qui l'avoit basty, et celuy qui y travailloit
notable_quotes.english: that she gave to the devil the said battand, and he who gave permission to build it, who built it, and he who worked on it

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Mengeon Galdrimey (threat about affairs)
notable_quotes.french: que ses affaires se porteroient bien tout ainsy droict comme une faucille
notable_quotes.english: that her affairs would go as straight as a sickle
notable_quotes.context: accusation of threat after property dispute

notable_quotes.speaker: Jennon femme Mengeon Galdrimey (public accusation)
notable_quotes.french: dit plusieurs fois haultement qu'il falloit brusler touttes les sorcieres pauvres et riches qui luy faisoient mourrir ses bestiaulx, et voulloit demander permission a Monsieur d'Estival d'aller apres d'ung devin pour scavoir qui estoit la sorciere que luy faisoit tant de maulx
notable_quotes.english: said several times loudly that it was necessary to burn all the witches poor and rich who made her animals die, and wanted to ask permission from Monsieur d'Estival to go to a diviner to know who was the witch causing so much harm
notable_quotes.context: public accusation when horse became ill

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacote Marechal (during interrogation about pigs)
notable_quotes.french: la rage que ledit Rolbey et sa femme seront enragez
notable_quotes.english: the rabies that said Rolbey and his wife will be enraged

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacote Marechal (about geese)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle a faict mourir ses fiebvres cartaines
notable_quotes.english: that she made his certain fevers die

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacote Marechal (about animals)
notable_quotes.french: qu'elle a faict mourrir le feu que ledit Galdrimey sera bruslé
notable_quotes.english: that she made the fire die that said Galdrimey will be burned

notable_quotes.speaker: Jacote Marechal (about charity)
notable_quotes.french: qu'il ne fault plus faire de bien puis qu'en faisant des aulmosnes on y trouve a redire
notable_quotes.english: that one must no longer do good since in giving alms one finds fault with it

notable_quotes.speaker: Curien (accused's son, sabbat boast)
notable_quotes.english: he had been to the Devil with his mother, where he had eaten 'oysillons', and a man dressed as a gentleman in black had danced with his mother
notable_quotes.context: children's dispute about who had traveled furthest

notable_quotes.speaker: Demenge Fallajeux le Jeune
notable_quotes.french: En fin il dit que c'estoit trop luy mener la guerre pour ledit battand, et ne craindoit que les sorcieres que luy puisse faire desplaisir
notable_quotes.english: In the end he said it was too much to wage war on him for the said battand, and he only feared the witches who could cause him displeasure

economic_context.details: Multiple property disputes over fields, gardens, and water rights. Business competition between tavern keepers (Jacote vs Barbon, Jacote vs Mengeon Galdrimey). Disputes over battand (mill wheel) construction permits and locations. Debt disputes over unreturned loans (peas). Property sales with seller's remorse when price deemed too low. Accused operated tavern with husband, indicating middling economic status.

extraction_metadata.notes: Very detailed trial with extensive witness testimony. Several children (ages 9-13) testified about Curien's boast of attending sabbat with his mother - significant as children's testimony. Multiple families report poisoning via food (tripes incident reported by two different families - witnesses 7 and 15). Pattern of illness/death following property disputes and business competition. Accused operated tavern with husband, had direct business competitors. Economic disputes central: fields, gardens, water rights, battand construction. Confession obtained under torture - thumbscrews ineffective (seen as diabolical), rack caused physical reaction. Accused initially retracted, then renewed confession. Named only already-executed accomplices. Unusual detail: paid devil a hen each Martinmas to avoid sabbat attendance. Trial moved quickly: 14 days from depositions to execution. Change de Nancy approved both torture and execution without modification.
